title: Fancy Food - The GameOverGreggy Show Ep. 185 (Pt. 4)
description:
How do you handle food you don't understand?

Subscribe! http://www.youtube.com/kindafunny?sub_confirmation=1

Support us and get the shows early here! http://www.patreon.com/kindafunny

Check out our store! http://www.kindafunny.com/store

Follow us on Twitter!
Greg - http://www.twitter.com/GameOverGreggy
Tim - http://www.twitter.com/TimGettys
Nick - http://www.twitter.com/Nick_Scarpino
Kinda Funny - http://www.twitter.com/KindaFunnyVids

Every day Greg Miller, Tim Gettys, and Nick Scarpino talk about the biggest stories in nerd culture.

transcript_chunks.text: Tim, what's your topic? My topic is fancy food. Last night, uh, as of the time of recording this, it was my girlfriend Gia's birthday. We decided to go out to this fancy French restaurant I was about to say "rest in peace," yeah, called Jardinière. I'm not sure starts with a "J" and ends with some "er" and like "Franklin" and like "Fank," yeah, it's around there. It's on Bush Grove Street, so it was there. And we walked by recently, and she was just like, "Oh, let's go there. It's really nice." My cool boyfriend booked that reservation that night. I was like, "I know what's up with this." We go there, it's just me, her, her sister, and her sister's boyfriend. And we walk in, and immediately I'm like, "Didn't even think about how fancy this place was." Inspired by the opera, by the way. Exactly. I was wearing a button-up shirt, so I lucked out there. But totally could have been wearing exactly this outfit, and they'd be fine. But we realized it's San Francisco; there's nowhere in San Francisco that you have to dress up. You wear fancy shorts.

the liver of a duck, also known as foie gras, which is produced by force-feeding ducks corn with a feeding tube, a process called gavage. In Spain and other countries, ducks are force-fed twice a day for 12.5 days, while geese are fed three times a day for around 17 days. Ducks are typically slaughtered at 100 days, and geese at 112.
